interlinear-text.item: Grunberg & Steblin-Kamensky. 1976/1988. La langue wakhi. Pt. 1 Corpus de litterature orale. Translated by Dominique Indjoudjian. Editions de la Maison des Sciences de L'homme Paris. p.56-64 (text 3)

phrase.item: Whether it is true or not, there once was an old woman, who had a grandson and a sheep.
The ewe lambed every day, and every day the grandmother and her grandson would eat the newborn lamb.
One day the grandson and his grandmother decided that, "We will kill our sheep...
...One day the head and foot, one day the stomach and intestines, and one day the hand and leg they ate...
...When the meat is finished, we will go to the court of the king, there we will collect crumbs on which we will live." The grandmother consented to this.
My grandmother agreed.
She said to her grandson: "Catch the sheep in the paddock."
The grandson caught the sheep.
So a cat began to jump gaily on the roof.
The ewe asked him: "Hey Cat, why do you rejoice so much that you jump on the roof?"
The cat said: "Today the old woman will kill you, and I will steal your tail!"
The ewe said: "Go fetch me a knife, I'll slice my tail myself and you will open the door for me!
The cat knew that it would, in truth, be difficult to steal the tail from the old woman.
He brought the ewe a knife.
The sheep cut his own tail and gave it to the cat.
The cat opened the door.
The sheep left, and went to Mount Qof.
There, she lambed every day until she had accumulated all around her an entire flock.
Then she gave birth to a human child.
A human child grows year by year, month by month, but Majzman [the son of the sheep], grew every day.
One day, his mother told him, an animal must live with animals, people must live with people.
Majzman said "you are my mother,
I don't want to know anyone else."
The sheep said "you are a man of this world
obey the one who taught you and you wil not lose face".
Majzman consented.
The mother gave him some hairs from her head and said "if you find yourself in trouble, burn these hairs and I will appear".
Majzman took the hairs from his mother, hid them in his belt, and set off.
He arrived at a place where he saw a man uproot a sycamore and then carry it around.
Majzman said to him: "What kind of person are you that you uproot a tree?"
The man said that "My name is brave Činorboz"
It is said that Majzman would have been born, a youth, the son of a sheep, and that he would be even stronger than me.
I want to fight him".
Majzman said "fight first with me"
If you defeat me, then you will be able to conquer Majzman as well
Činorboz and Majzman began to fight
Majzman struck him with a turn.
He pulled out his knife to kill him
but Činorboz said "you are an only child, I will be your brother"
Majzman pulled Činorboz up off of the ground
They went farther and came across a man who played with an entire mountain, taking it in his hand.
So who are you, you who plays with a mountain? they asked
He said "my name is Kuboz"
They say that a young fighter, Majzman, son of a sheep, was born. I will fight him.
Majzman said "first fight me"
If you can defeat me, then you can also defeat Majzman.
They began to fight.
Majzman defeated him.
He wanted to kill him but the other said "of what use to you will a spoonful of my blood be?
You are two brothers, I will be your third brother.
Then Majzman took Kuboz by the hand and lifted him off the ground.
They went farther and came across a man who twirled a millstone on his finger.
They asked him "what kind of person are you that you twirl a stone with a hole on your finger?"
He said "my name is Xedorgboz"
A brave young man named Majzman has been born
is the -kit metathesis of -tk?
I want to fight him.
Majzman said "first fight with me"
"If you defeat me, then you can defeat Majzman too"
They fought each other.
Majzman defeated this one too
He held up his knife
but the other said "of what use will a spoonful of my blood be to you?"
"You are three brothers, I will be your fourth brother"
Majzman kicked him, and lifted him off the ground.
The four brothers went farther
They arrived at a place where they saw a house
They walked around the house, but there was no door
So they climbed onto the roof but there was no chimney
Suddenly the chimney appeared
The brothers looked down and saw that it was so high that it was impossible to descend
Suddenly the door of the house appeared
They went inside and there everything was ready for a meal, but nobody was there
They looked in the corners and found nobody
So the brothers washed their hands and sat down to eat.
"We will live in this house," they decided.
We will go hunting every day
What we kill, we will bring back here, cook, eat, and live on
They spent the night in the house and in the morning got up to go hunting
They returned from hunting and saw that in the house a meal was again ready.
So they held council and decided that one of them must stay and observe what happens
They decided: "That our eldest brother Cinorboz stays, what will he see?"
In the morning, the other brothers went hunting.
Cinorboz looked a little on all sides and then fell asleep.
But in one of the pillars of the house, there was a crack
From it came a young girl
She prepared a meal, washed Cinorboz's face, applied makeup to his eyes, placed a plate of food before him.
She transformed into a needle and jumped into the crack in the pillar.
Cinorboz awoke and saw that there was makeup on his eyes, that his beard had been smeared with oil, that a plate of food was before him, but nobody was there.
Cinorboz busied himself, washed his face with earth, ate some of the food, and left the rest for his brothers.
Then arrived his friends, who asked: "Well then, what have you seen?"
"Nothing," responded Cinorboz
In turn they left. Kuboz, then Xedorgboz.
But, like Cinorboz, they could not see anything.
Majzman said "you are blind!
I will stay, what will I see?
Majzman thought and decided to cut his little finger and he poured salt onto the cut.
On his head he put a short kaftan into which he poked two eyeholes.
Majzman's finger hurt and he did not fall asleep.
The whole time, he looked through the openings in the kaftan
He saw a young girl come out of a slot in a pillar. She prepared to eat, washed his face, smeared oil on his beard.
She lay before him a plate of food and began to transform into a needle.
Then Mayzman seized her by the tail of her dress
The young girl struggled; Majzman pulled her.
The young girl asked "If you take me as your wife, what will Cinorboz say? If Cinorboz weds me, what will Kuboz say?
If Kuboz weds me, what will Xedorgboz say?"
Majzman said "Stay until my friends return"
Suddenly when the brothers returned, the sight of the young girl filled them with great joy
Then Majzman proposed to Cinorboz: "Take her as your wife!"
"She is my sister, never!" responded Cinorboz
Majzman asked Kuboz who responded: "She is forever my aunt"
Majzman asked Xedorgboz and he said "She is my mother forever"
So Majzman said "I take her myself as my wife"
Majzman ordered his wife tgo tend to the fire in the hearth so that it should never go out.
One day the brothers left for the forest to go hunting, the young wife rested alone
She got bored, climbed onto the roof, and began to string a necklace on the edge of the chimney
a red bead feell directly onto the hearth
The young wife looked down to see if the fire was burning or not
She saw something reddening in the fire, but when she went down and entered the house, then she saw that the fire had gone out and that that thing was the bead
[to audience] Who will get fire for her in the desert?
Then the young wife climbed onto the roof, looked in all directions and in the distance glimpsed smoke rising from a cave.
The young wife headed toward the smoke.
Once she reached it, she listened at the door and heard a crackling
She glanced through the door and (saw that) Barzangi was cooking toasted wheat, lice and nits.
The young wife sprang back, but Barzangi saw her and said: "Enter! I am the sister of your mother, what do you need?"
"My fire has gone out," responded the young wife, "give me fire".
Barzangi poured grilled lice and nits into her sleeve and he said "sprinkle lice and nits on the path from my house to your house, and the dung will ignite in your hearth"
The young wife left and sprinkled the path with lice and nits
The fire in her hearth alighted but she prepared the meal later than usual
One day, the boys set off again for the hunt
The young wife stayed alone at home and suddenly heard a voice behind the door: "I arrive in my hour on a goat, a sheep at the bridle, needles in my belt, a plate on my head, bread on my chest.
open the door, I'm here!"
The young wife opened the door for him
Barzangi lay down the plate, put the bread on it, drove the needles into the bread and ordered: "Knead!"
The young wife began to knead the bread; much blood was shed.
Barzangi ate the bloodied bread and went back home
When Majzman returned with his friends, he saw taht his wife was limping
"What is it?" he asked
The woman responded "my leg hurts" In the morning, once again, Majzman left with his friends to hunt
Barzangi returned and said, behind the door "I arrive in my hour on a goat, a sheep at the bridle, needles in my belt, a plate on my head, bread on my chest.
Open the door, I'm here!
The young wife, once again, opened the door for him.
Barzangi lay down the plate, put the bread on it, drove the needles into the bread.
Once again, the young wife began to knead the bread.
Blood mixed with the bread. Barzangi drank the blood and packed up.
Majzman returned from hunting: his wife was quite hurt
She could not walk.
Although Majzman questioned her, she told him nothing.
So Majzman and his friends agreed that one of them would stay and shed light on this matter "Let our eldest brother Cinorboz stay!" they decided "we will know what he sees"
Cinorboz stayed; the others went hunting.
Once more, Barzangi arrived at the door,
and he said "I arrive in my hour on a goat, a sheep at the bridle, needles in my belt, a plate on my head, bread on my chest"
Open the door, I'm here!
Cinorboz asked "who's there?"
"Hide yourself," said the young wife, "or else he will eat us, you and me"
Cinorboz hid himself.
Barzangi entered and did everything as he had the other days.
He drank the blood, ate, and packed up.
The friends returned from hunting and did not see anything in particular, save that the young wife was very hurt.
They could obtain nothing from Cinorboz
In turn, they left Kuboz, then Xedorgboz, but, like Cinorboz, they could not see anything.
So Majzman decided to stay himself
During the day, Barzangi arrived once more. He repeated his usual words: "I arrive in my hour on a goat, a sheep at the bridle, needles in my belt, a plate on my head, bread on my chest"
Open the door, I'm here!
Majzman asked his wife: "What's this all about?"
She said "I don't know"
Majzman opened the door
Barzangi entered and said to Majzman: "Prepare me a hookah!"
Majzman prepared him a hookah.
Barzangi drew a breath, and Majzman struck him with his dagger.
But Barzangi had seven heads. One head fled, one head fell in the cave, but (Majzman) killed the five others.
The head that had fled gathered a troop and arrived one morning to do battle.,
Majzman began, with his friends, to confront the troop.
They exterminated the whole troop, and they themselves drowned in the blood.
Then Majzman recalled that his mother had given him the hairs from her head.
He cried out to his wife "in my belt there are some hairs, burn them!"
She burned the hairs in the fire
Iimmediately the ewe appeared bleating. She pulled her son from the blood, licked him and asked "who else is there besides you?"
Majzman showed her Cinorboz, Kuboz and Xedorgboz.
The ewe withdrew them from the blood.
Thereafter she said her goodbyes to her son and went away
But Majzman was very upset that one of Barzangi's heads had slipped into the cave.
He said to his friends "One head fell, let someone go down and see"
First they decided to send down the eldest brother Cinorboz
They attached a rope to Cinorboz's belt, let him down, and he yelled "Oh, I'm dead! Oh, I'm dead!"
Then he was taken back up.
In the same way they attached Kuboz and Xedorgboz with a rope, and let htem down. They too, cried out: "Oh, I'm dead!" and were let back up
So Majzman ordered that they let him down, even if he cried "Oh, I'm dead!"
He was let down and began to cry out "Oh, I'm dead! Oh, I'm dead!"
Nevertheless, he was let down and Majzman found himself in the other world.
[to audience] Who would bring him back up?
In the other world, Barzangi was a shepherd.
Majzman approached the shepherd
The shepherd asked "which man are you?"
"When grandfather Barzangi had fought," responded Majzman, "I hid here"
He brought the shepherd great joy and Majzman began to ask him all kinds of questions. "How can you enumerate so many cattle?" asked Majzman
"Is it possible that you don't know," responded the shepherd, "that near our house there is a tree on which leaves grow every day?
If in the evening you strike the trunk and all the leaves fall, then that means that all the cattle are present.
If on the other hand the leaves do not fall, that means taht cattle are missing."
Then Majzman asked "And how can one cross this river?"
The shepherd replied "Go up to the bank and say "Cak!" the water will withdraw, and when you say "Pak!" the water will flow.
"And where is the soul of our grandfather?" asked Majzman
The shepherd responded "his soul is in this crook
if the crook is broken on the knee, then our grandfather will pass away."
"And where does the soul of our grandmother reside?" Majzman continued to ask
"Her soul is in the rocks with which salt is ground," responded the shepherd.
"If the rocks are struck, one against the other, then a wick will alight.
If you put out the wick, our grandmother will die.
"Where does your soul reside?" asked Majzman
The shepherd responded: "My soul is in an enormous louse that I have on my head
If it is killed, my soul will leave me.
Then, Majzman proposed to the shepherd to squash his lice.
"But do not kill the big louse" said the shepherd
"I am no man" said Majzman "to kill with my own hands a first cousin!"
So the shepherd consented.
Majzman began to kill the lice
Suddenly, he saw a big louse.
"How big it is" Majzman marvelled
"In it resides my soul" said the shepherd
Majzman killed the louse
The shepherd passed away
Majzman pressed into his head the entrails that were ont he shepherd's head and pushed the cattle forward
Having reached the edge of the river, he said "Cak!"
The water receded.
Once he crossed the river, on the other bank, he said "Pak!"
The river flowed again.
Majzman reached the gate.
He kicked the tree, all the leaves fell.
Majzman rejoiced that all the cattle were present.
Then an old woman arrived to milk the cattle and ordered: "bring an ewe!"
He brought her a ram.
Bring a doe!
He brought her a buck.
The old woman asked "What happened to you, do you not understand anything anymore?"
"Every day I pasture the cattle under a burning sun," said Majzman, "the sun beats down on my head"
"Go in the house," ordered the old woman, "your grandfather has fried lice and nits in his belt"
Eat them and you will recover
Majzman entered the house
He seized the crook and broke it.
The grandfather died, but the old woman knew nothing of it.
Then he hit, one against the other, the stones which serve to grind salt. Suddenly, the wick ignited.
Majzman extinguished it.
The old woman passed away.
Then Majzman led the whole herd...
...bringing them to the place where he had descneded from this world to the other world.
There, he cried and his friends sent down a rope.
Majzman began to attach the sheep and the goats one by one to the rope and his friends hoisted them up.
Finally, he cried "hoist me!"
But he himself stayed at the bottom.
His friends pulled the rope nad close to the top they let it fall back down.
"I did well to have stayed" thought Majzman "or else not I would already be a corpse"
Majzman set off again at the bottom.
He reached the thorny scrub that had grown onto the leg of the bird Simurgh.
But Simurgh felt bad.
"What is it?" asked Majzman
"No one can release me"
Majzman asked "If I release you, what will you do for me?"
"All that you desire, I will do it" responded Simurgh
"So be it, let's see" said Majzman
Majzman took his dagger and began to cut the thorns that had pressed into Simurgh's leg.
He cut so many of them that he had liberated it. There remained only a small root in the leg.
Simurgh was delighted: "You are very strong! I suggest that you dig a pit here and sliip into it.
When you have extracted the last root, it is possible that I will pass out and then my children will kill you."
Majzman dug the pit and slipped in.
Simurgh sat on top.
Majzman pulled out the root from her leg.
Simurgh passed out.
Suddenly, her children appeared; they saw their mother passed out and said: "If it is a bird who did this, we will pull out its wings, b ut if it is someone else, we will turn them into ashes!"
Then Simurgh came to and said: "An ordinary man is worth more than you, because he has released me."
The children asked: "Well where is he? We will cover him with kisses!"
Then Simurgh withdrew to the side.
Majzman left the pit and the children embraced him.
"What do you desire?" asked Simurgh
"I want but one thing," responded Majzman, "that you take me back up to the world above"
"If this is so," said Simurgh, "then gather for me provisions for the road."
Majzman went ot the city.
There he gathered and prepared in a big basket all that he found: meat, bread, some carrion
Simurgh seated him on a wing and placed the food on the other wing.
They took off and Majzman began to put the food in her beak.
When they had already almost climbed to the top, Simurgh said: "Oh, I'm dying!"
But the provisions were exhausted.
Majzman cut flesh from his arm and stuffed it into her beak.
But he still did not succeed in climbing and it was necessary to turn back
In the morning, Majzman gathered even more supplies
Again, Simurgh seated him on a wing and began to beat her wings.
They approached the world above and again the provisions were exhausted.
"Oh, I'm dead!" said Simurgh
Majzman cut flesh from his lega nd stuffed it into her beak. Simurgh put Majzman down in this world.
"Young man, what is your name?" asked the bird Simurgh
"My name is Majzman", he said.
Simurgh asked: "What kind of meat did you give me yesterday and finally today? It was very tasty."
At first Majzman didn't say anything.
Then he said "Yesterday I cut the flesh from my arm, and today from my leg"
Simurgh regurgitated the pieces of meat.
-as?
Simurgh put them back in their places: his arm and his leg were as before.
Then Simurgh said "young man, you are very brave
I will give you something more"
With these words, Simurgh plucked two feathers, one white and the other black
"Take this," she said.
"Strike yourself with the white feather and you will become a thousand years old
Strike yourself with the black feather and you will become a young man even more beautiful than before."
Simurgh said goodbye to him.
Majzman hit himself with the white feather.
He went home as a thousand year old man, where he saw his friends Cinorboz, Kuboz, and Xedorgboz were preparing to wash their hands before eating.
"Hey old man!" they said
why don't you get up and pour some water on our hands!"
Majzman did not want to.
So they said: "Either pour water on our hands, or else get out of the house or we'll kill you!"
Majzman was infuriated.
He struck himself with the black feather and became even more beautiful than before.
He unsheathed his dagger and in a single blow cut off their heads.
Afterwards, Majzman lived happily with his wife.
You too, good willing you too will be happy.
